settings.title: How HeadCoach transcends and includes traditional sport psychology frameworks

settings.editor: A Comparative Analysis of Mental Training Approaches

Robin Vealey's (2024) comprehensive framework for mental training in sport represents the current state-of-the-art in sport psychology academic thinking. Published in the Journal of Applied Sport Psychology, her model articulates how mental performance consultants work with athletes through philosophies, models, strategies, and techniques to build mental skills and mental health.

HeadCoach's Integral+ approach doesn't reject this framework—it transcends and includes it.

This article demonstrates how the Integral+ methodology operates at a higher level of developmental complexity while honoring and incorporating the valuable contributions of traditional sport psychology frameworks like Vealey's.

Elite mental training frameworks have continued to evolve, with recent advancements in sport psychology organizing mental training into:

Core Components:

1. Consultant Philosophy & Model of Practice

  • Theoretical foundations (CBT, humanistic, acceptance-based)
  • Structured models (MAC, REBT, IZOF)
  • Strategies and techniques (imagery, self-talk, goal setting)

2. Four Categories of Mental Skills

  • Personal Foundation Skills: Motivation, self-awareness, productive thinking, self-confidence, mindfulness/acceptance, self-compassion
  • Performance Skills: Perceptual-cognitive ability, attentional focus, energy management
  • Personal Development Skills: Identity achievement, interpersonal competence, lifestyle management, leadership
  • Team Skills: Communication, psychological safety, cohesion, team confidence

3. Mental Health as Wellbeing

  • Emotional wellbeing (hedonic)
  • Psychological wellbeing (eudaimonic functioning)
  • Social wellbeing (community connection)

4. Outcomes

  • Performance enhancement
  • Personal development
  • Experience optimization (satisfaction, flow, enjoyment)
[from Vealey, R. S. (2024). A framework for mental training in sport: Enhancing mental skills, wellbeing, and performance. Journal of Applied Sport Psychology, 36(2), 365-384.]

What this gets right:

  • Comprehensiveness: Moves beyond just "performance skills" to include development and wellbeing
  • Mental health integration: Recognizes that mental performance consultants should address subclinical mental health, not just refer out
  • Hard and soft skills: Acknowledges both traditional "toughness" skills and newer acceptance-based approaches
  • Process orientation: Shows the flow from philosophy → model → strategies → techniques
  • Sociocultural awareness: Acknowledges context matters

This is excellent work. Vealey has synthesized decades of sport psychology research into a usable framework for practitioners.Rece

settings.title: Where Traditional Frameworks Fall Short: The Developmental Blind Spot

settings.editor:
Despite its sophistication, Vealey's framework—like most sport psychology models—operates primarily within a single developmental stage (what integral theory calls "Orange-Green" or "achievement-pluralistic" consciousness).

The Missing Dimensions:

No Developmental Lens

  • Assumes all athletes process mental skills the same way
  • Doesn't account for different stages of psychological maturity
  • No recognition that how an athlete makes meaning determines what interventions will work

Flat Skills Model

  • Lists skills as if they're all equivalent and equally accessible
  • Doesn't show how skills build developmentally
  • No recognition that some skills require more cognitive complexity than others

Limited Perspective Work

  • Mentions "self-awareness" but doesn't systematically train perspective-taking
  • No explicit framework for 1st/2nd/3rd person view flexibility
  • Doesn't recognize that psychological growth IS perspective growth

Consultant-Centric

  • Framework centers on what consultants do TO/FOR athletes
  • Limited emphasis on athlete agency and self-authorship
  • Doesn't explicitly develop athletes' capacity to become their own mental performance experts

Meaning making - epistemology

  • No recognition that different athletes have different truth-validation systems
  • Assumes rational-empirical knowing works for everyone

settings.title: The Integral+ Difference: Adding Developmental Altitude

settings.editor: HeadCoach's Integral+ approach includes everything valuable from Vealey's framework but adds crucial dimensions that exponentially increase effectiveness.

settings.title: Key Distinction #1: Lines of Development, Not Just Skills Lists

settings.editor:
Vealey's Approach:
Lists mental skills across four categories (foundation, performance, development, team) as relatively flat, trainable capabilities.

Integral+ Approach:
Recognizes that mental skills develop along multiple independent lines (cognitive, emotional, moral, interpersonal, somatic) and that athletes can be at different stages on different lines.

Example: An athlete might have:

  • Elite cognitive line (sophisticated tactical thinking)
  • Underdeveloped emotional line (struggle with regulation)
  • Strong interpersonal line (natural leadership)
  • Emerging self-identity line (still forming independent sense of self)

The Integral+ Advantage: We assess developmental altitude on each line and design interventions matched to where the athlete actually is, not where we think they should be.

This is why generic "confidence building" exercises fail—they're designed for athletes at a specific developmental stage. We meet athletes where they are and build from there.

settings.title: Key Distinction #2: Quadrant Mapping - The AQAL Framework

settings.editor:
Vealey's Approach:
Mentions "sociocultural environment" but treats it as external context rather than integral to the system.

Integral+ Approach:
Every mental performance challenge exists simultaneously in Wilber's four quadrants:

  • UL (Upper-Left / Interior-Individual): Thoughts, beliefs, mindset, internal narrative
  • UR (Upper-Right / Exterior-Individual): Behaviors, physiology, performance data
  • LL (Lower-Left / Interior-Collective): Team culture, shared values, relationships
  • LR (Lower-Right / Exterior-Collective): Systems, structures, organizational design

image.alt: Illustration of the Quadrants in a 2 x 2 matrix

settings.editor:
The Integral+ Advantage:
When an athlete says "I'm not confident," traditional sport psychology stays in UL (thoughts/beliefs) and UR (performance stats).

Integral+ asks:

  • UL (Interior-Individual): What's your internal narrative? What meaning are you making?
  • UR (Exterior-Individual): What behaviours/preparation rituals support confidence? What's your physiological state?
  • LL (Interior-Collective): What's the team culture around confidence? Do teammates model vulnerability or invincibility? What's your relationship with your coach?
  • LR (Exterior-Collective): What organizational systems reward or punish risk-taking? What's the training structure? How does performance measurement impact confidence?

We intervene in ALL four quadrants simultaneously.

This is why HeadCoach works with teams AND individuals, coaches AND athletes, culture AND psychology. You can't optimize one quadrant in isolation.

settings.title: Key Distinction #3: Stages of Development - Meeting Athletes Where They Are

settings.editor:
Vealey's Approach:
Assumes athletes are cognitively ready for self-reflection, metacognition, and rational self-regulation (essentially Orange/Green stage capacities).

Integral+ Approach:
Explicitly assesses and works with developmental stage:

StageCharacteristicsMental Training Approach
Red (Impulsive-Egocentric)Power-oriented, immediate gratification, "what's in it for me?"Direct, authoritative, consequence-based. Focus on channeling aggression, establishing boundaries. Coach as authority figure.
Amber (Conformist-Mythic)Rule-following, tradition, belonging, "the right way"Clear structures, rituals, team identity. Confidence through role fulfillment. Coach as wise guide providing certainty.
Orange (Achievement-Strategic)Goal-oriented, rational, competitive, "what works?"Performance metrics, evidence-based techniques, strategic planning. Confidence through competence. Coach as expert consultant.
Green (Pluralistic-Egalitarian)Relationship-focused, empathetic, consensus, "everyone's perspective matters"Collaborative goal-setting, emotional intelligence, values exploration. Confidence through authenticity. Coach as facilitator.
Teal (Integral-Systemic)Systems-thinking, paradox-holding, self-authoring, "multiple truths"Meta-awareness practices, perspective flexibility, identity architecture. Confidence through self-knowledge. Coach as developmental partner.

Example: Athlete struggling with confidence after benching:

  • Red-stage athlete: "Coach doesn't respect me" → Intervention: Re-establish power/agency, create opportunities to fully express one's self in training
  • Amber-stage athlete: "I violated team standards" → Intervention: Clarify expectations, restore role/status through adherence
  • Orange-stage athlete: "I'm not performing to my potential" → Intervention: Analyse performance data, optimise preparation, create a plan
  • Green-stage athlete: "I feel disconnected from my authentic self" → Intervention: Values clarification, relationship repair, collaborative inquiry via coaching
  • Teal-stage athlete: "I'm attached to an identity that's no longer serving me" → Intervention: Identity architecture, perspective work, shadow work

The same "confidence issue" requires completely different interventions based on developmental stage.

Traditional sport psychology uses Orange/Green interventions for everyone. That's why so much mental training doesn't work.

settings.title: Key Distinction #4: The Identity Compass - Cognitive Preferences as Leverage

settings.editor:
Vealey's Approach:
Acknowledges individual differences but doesn't systematically assess and leverage cognitive biases.

Integral+ Approach:
The Identity Compass reveals 16+ dimensions of unconscious cognitive preferences that determine how athletes:

  • Take in information (sensory channel, primary interest)
  • Motivate themselves (toward/away, internal/external reference)
  • Process during performance (perceptual-cognitive, attentional, energy)
  • Make decisions (detail/global, concrete/abstract, options/procedures)

The Integral+ Advantage:
If an athlete has:

  • High external reference → Building confidence through internal validation won't work until we first build internal authority
  • Detail preference → Global "just focus on the process" coaching will fail without breaking down specific steps
  • Away-motivated → Purely positive "toward" goal-setting creates no motivational pull
  • High second-person perspective → They're constantly in "what do others think?" mode and need first/third-person development

We don't just teach mental skills—we teach them in the LANGUAGE the athlete's nervous system already speaks.

This is why HeadCoach athletes report "finally, someone who gets how my brain works."

settings.title: Key Distinction #5: Shadow Work - The Missing Element

settings.editor:
Vealey's Approach:
Mentions "self-awareness" but doesn't systematically address unconscious material, projection, or disowned parts.

Integral+ Approach:
Explicit shadow work is core to our methodology.

Shadow framework:

  • Shadow projection identification
  • Recognition of disowned traits (dark and golden)
  • Reclamation and integration processes
  • 3-2-1 shadow work (face it, talk to it, be it)

Example: Athlete who "hates arrogant competitors":

  • Traditional approach: Manage emotions, focus on your process, don't worry about others
  • Integral+ approach:
    • Recognize projection: The arrogance you see in them is golden shadow/confidence you won't claim
    • Own it: "I am arrogant" (in healthy, context-appropriate ways)
    • Integrate it: Develop conscious access to healthy self-assertion and presence
    • Result: Emotional charge disappears, performance improves, you reclaim your power

Athletes don't just have mental skills deficits—they have disowned capacities.

Shadow work is systematically absent from sport psychology because most consultants operate from Green-stage "everyone is perfect as they are" assumptions. We know better.

settings.title: Key Distinction #6: State Work - The Phenomenological Dimension

settings.editor:
Vealey's Approach:
Focuses on cognitive and behavioural skills, with some attention to "energy management" and mindfulness.

Integral+ Approach:
Explicit state training across multiple dimensions:

State TypeTraining MethodOutcome
Gross (wakeful)Cognitive skills, self-talk, focusTraditional performance skills
SubtleImagery, visualization, mental rehearsalEnhanced preparation and recovery
CausalRecovery protocols, sleep hygiene, underlying mental structures that may limit and/or supportPhysiological restoration, inquiry/developmental coaching
WitnessMindfulness, meditation, centringPresent-moment awareness
Non-dualFlow state training, effortless performancePeak performance states

The Integral+ Advantage:

"We don't just train what athletes think, we train what state they're in when they think it."

  • Pre-performance routines that shift state (not just behaviour)
  • Flow state triggers and maintenance
  • Recovery states (not just physical, but consciousness-based)
  • Witness consciousness for pressure situations

This is why Integral+ athletes report "I found a gear I didn't know I had."

settings.title: Key Distinction #7: From External Consultant to Self-Authoring Athlete

settings.editor:
Vealey's Approach:
Framework centres on consultant delivering services to athletes (philosophy → model → strategies → techniques → outcomes).

Integral+ Approach:
The goal is to make the athlete their own expert (self-management, self-leadership)

We teach the meta-frameworks:

  • Here's how development works (stages)
  • Here's how your mind creates biases (Identity Compass)
  • Here's how to work with multiple perspectives (1st/2nd/3rd/4th person)
  • Here's how to recognise and integrate shadow
  • Here's how to access different states
  • Here's how all four quadrants influence your performance

The Integral+ Advantage:
After working with HeadCoach, athletes can:

  • Self-diagnose where they're stuck
  • Self-prescribe appropriate interventions
  • Self-correct when strategies aren't working
  • Self-evolve through increasingly complex challenges

We don't create dependency, we create autonomy at a higher level of complexity.

settings.title: Transcend and Include: A Visual Comparison

settings.editor:
What Vealey's Framework Includes (That We Also Include):

  • ✅ Comprehensive mental skills across multiple categories
  • ✅ Mental health and wellbeing as core outcomes
  • ✅ Both hard skills (focus, confidence) and soft skills (self-compassion, acceptance)
  • ✅ Individual AND team-level interventions
  • ✅ Recognition that consultant philosophy matters
  • ✅ Awareness of sociocultural context
  • ✅ Integration of mindfulness and acceptance-based approaches
  • ✅ Personal development alongside performance

This is all excellent. We don't abandon any of it.

What Integral+ ADDS (Transcendence):

  • ➕ Developmental stages - Meeting athletes where they are, not where we want them to be
  • ➕ Lines of development - Independent growth trajectories across cognitive, emotional, moral, interpersonal domains
  • ➕ Quadrant awareness - Simultaneous intervention across interior/exterior and individual/collective
  • ➕ Identity Compass - Systematic assessment and leveraging of cognitive biases
  • ➕ State work - Training across waking, dreaming, witness, and flow states
  • ➕ Shadow integration - Systematic reclamation of disowned capacities
  • ➕ Perspective flexibility - Explicit training in 1st/2nd/3rd person views
  • ➕ Epistemological sophistication - Recognising different ways of knowing truth
  • ➕ Self-authorship development - Athletes becoming their own experts
  • ➕ Vertical development - Not just skill building, but consciousness evolution

When Traditional Approaches Work:

  • Athlete is Orange/Green stage with good self-awareness
  • Challenge is technical/tactical, not developmental
  • Athlete has internal authority and just needs skills
  • Environment is supportive and psychologically safe
  • Pressure is manageable and athlete has good coping

In these conditions, Vealey's framework is excellent.

When Traditional Approaches Fail:

  • Athlete is at Red/Amber stage and can't access rational self-reflection
  • Challenge is identity-based, not skill-based
  • Athlete has high external reference and no internal authority
  • Environment is toxic or systemically undermining
  • Pressure triggers deep shadow material or developmental regression

In these conditions, only developmental, integral approaches work.

The Integral+ Advantage:

We can work at ANY level with ANY athlete in ANY context.

  • Red-stage athlete in toxic environment? We can work there.
  • Teal-stage athlete seeking existential meaning? We can work there.
  • Orange-stage athlete needing tactical confidence? We can work there.
  • Team culture destroying individual wellbeing? We can work there.

This is why HeadCoach has 20+ years of consistent results across:

  • Youth athletes to Olympic champions
  • Individual sports to team sports
  • Corporate executives to military personnel
  • Injury rehabilitation to peak performance

We meet the client where they are and work with what's actually present, not what we wish was present.

settings.title: Academic Rigor: Why Integral+ Is Evidence-Based

settings.editor:
Vealey's Framework Rests On:

  • 40+ years of sport psychology research
  • Meta-analyses showing mental training improves performance
  • Intervention studies demonstrating technique efficacy
  • Clinical case studies across populations

This research base is solid and we honour it.

Integral+ ADDS Research From:

  • Developmental psychology (Kegan, Cook-Greuter, Loevinger, Kohlberg, Gilligan)
  • Integral theory (Wilber, Esbjörn-Hargens, Hamilton)
  • Adult development (Torbert, Rooke, stage transitions)
  • Cognitive science (NLP, cognitive biases, predictive processing)
  • Depth psychology (Jung, shadow work, projection)
  • Phenomenology (state training, consciousness research)
  • Systems theory (Meadows, Senge, organisational development)
  • Neuroscience (polyvagal theory, embodied cognition, neuroplasticity)

Our model is built on a MORE comprehensive research base, not less.

The difference is we're pulling from Level 2 sciences (developmental psychology, integral theory, systems theory) not just Level 1 sciences (sport psychology intervention studies).

image.alt: Table illustrating key differences between traditional sports psychology and the Intergral+ elite model

settings.editor:
HeadCoach's Integral+ approach is not AGAINST traditional sport psychology.

We don't reject Vealey's framework, we transcend and include it.

Everything valuable in her model—mental skills, mental health, consultant effectiveness, technique selection, outcome focus—is fully present in our work.

But we add:

  • Developmental sophistication that meets athletes where they are
  • Integral mapping across quadrants, stages, lines, states, and types
  • Identity architecture that rewires unconscious cognitive biases
  • Shadow integration that reclaims disowned capacities
  • Vertical development that evolves consciousness, not just skills
  • Self-authorship that creates autonomous, expert athletes

This is the future of mental performance consulting.

Not because it's trendy or complicated, but because it works at a deeper level with more athletes in more contexts with more lasting results.

settings.title: Transcend and Include: A Visual Comparison

settings.editor:
About HeadCoach

HeadCoach delivers elite mental performance coaching through an Integral+ methodology that transcends traditional sport psychology while including all evidence-based practices.

Founded by Jay Hedley, with 20+ years experience including:

  • Red Bull and Williams F1 (Alex Albon, Patrick Harding)
  • Fiji Rugby 7s (Olympic Gold, Tokyo 2021, Olympic Silver, Paris 2024)
  • Fijiana Women’s 15s Rugby (2025 World Cup UK)
  • Department of Defence (executive leadership)
  • Numerous individual elite athletes across amateur and professional sports – eg. Michael Conlan, Ireland, World champion (amateur) and World challenger (professional).

The Integral+ difference:

  • Developmental assessment (stages, lines, states)
  • Identity Compass cognitive profiling
  • Shadow integration work
  • Quadrant-mapped interventions
  • Vertical development focus
  • Self-authorship cultivation

settings.title:
"Traditional sport psychology teaches athletes WHAT to think. 
Integral+ teaches athletes HOW to think—and then evolves the thinker."
